You can read our Privacy Notice here. JOIN OUR WHATSAPP COMMUNITY HERE Q: Will your back-room staff remain the same? WG: "That's something we are talking about. The backroom staff that I've got at the moment, everyone is on different cycles. "It's about sitting down with them and talking with them along with talking to Nigel and the union about how we potentially go forward on those same contract cycles. I've seen a huge amount of growth from the staff since the Six Nations in terms of the work and effort they've put in and what we've learnt as coaches and the relationship we've developed over the last four or five months. "It's been extremely positive and we can see it from certain aspects of the side where coaches have got a lot more confident in this pressure cooker environment and also working with the players." Q: How do you manage the process with the older players over the next few years in terms of bringing in the next generation? WG : "It's looking at that age profile and looking at 2027 and thinking who in your mind is definitely not going to get there. Are there one or two who are part of the transition in terms of helping bringing youngsters through who have got that experience over the next 12 months or so. "It's going to be a balancing act for us. I have spoken to some of those older players in terms of what their plans are and where they see themselves over the next couple of years. Some will continue to want to play regional rugby and still be available. It's just making sure we have honest and open conversations about what is going to happen. "That's going to happen over the next couple of months. I spoke to Taulupe (Faletau) before he left France and I said get that arm fixed and then we'll sit down to talk about what you want to do over the next few years in terms of your playing. "It's making sure we get it right. We are aware we need to give those youngsters opportunities. They need time in the middle and I don't want to leave some of them with not playing much international rugby over the next couple of years and then trying to get them up to speed in a short period. "That's something there'll be some positive discussions around but every individual will be treated a little bit differently." Q: Do you think with a better relationship with the regions more promising youngsters will get given an opportunity? WG: "It has been frustrating in the past because we’ve identified some talent and had to use the international stage to develop them. Things have changed and there are now fewer overseas players at the regions. "The salary cap and everyone having to be conscious on the amount of money being spent on players to keep within budgets is a positive for younger players. They are going to get more opportunities at their regions. "It was a cycle that we went through for a number of years when we had some talented players coming out of the U20s who would then move into the regional programme. If they weren’t quite ready for regional rugby it meant the youngsters wouldn’t get a chance because of the pressure on coaches to get results. "Then they get to 23 and they’ve only played a dozen to 15 games. His agent would then knock on the door when the contracts were up for renewal and ask for a bit more money. They wouldn’t then give them any more and the coaches would go back to another 19-year-old. "We saw that cycle for a long time when they didn’t get the chances. The regions need to give their youngsters opportunities and I think they will now do that. Do they have talent? Yes; will they make mistakes? Yes; do you have to go through some pain with them? Absolutely. My biggest argument in the past was we were signing overseas players of 27-28 who had played Super Rugby or provincial rugby and at the time were better than those youngsters. "As result we didn’t see some of that development in them. We are in a position now where there aren’t anywhere near as many foreign players and the regions are having to be more proactive in developing their youngsters. I’d like to see them come through." Q: Do you support more opportunities for Tier Two nations? WG: "I thought Portugal were one of the teams of the tournament. They were absolutely outstanding in the way they played. "They benefitted from having a number of players coming from their sevens programme. They were a tough team. I didn’t realise until afterwards that the pool we were in was pretty even. The score we put on Georgia was the biggest amount of points they had conceded since the 2019 World Cup. They just need to play more rugby at a high level. Even the Uruguay game against the All Blacks was 0-0 after 20 minutes. "You can see what those team can do when the adrenalin is pumped up. The difficulty for them is sustaining it beyond the 60-70-minute mark. They just need the chance to play against the best. "When I first came to Wales, Roger Lewis asked me who do you want to play, I just said that any time you get the chance to play against a southern hemisphere side just jump at it. The only way we are going to get better is by playing against the best. "World Rugby has that responsibility to grow the game and maybe we all need to be a bit more open minded in the future about what happens to the Six Nations. Can that grow a little bit, or how do we run the Tier 2 Six Nations with the possibility of relegation and promotion moving forward? "There is a lot of money and jeopardy involved in that, but if we aren’t ambitious in terms of growing the game then we will continue to have the same top teams dominating. As a sports fan you want to see upsets. "We’ve seen that at the Cricket World Cup with the Netherlands beating South Africa and Afghanistan beating England. Because of the regular fixtures they’ve had against the bigger nations we have seen them develop. In some way we need to follow the same model to keep developing the Tier Two nations." Q: Will you appoint co-captains again? "I felt they both did outstanding jobs in their roles. I haven’t thought further ahead on that. Jac Morgan was absolutely outstanding. One of the questions I asked myself afterwards was did we get the No 6 and No 7 combination right in the quarter-final. "It was quite a big debating point among the coaches. Jac was one of the best 7s at the World Cup and we took him away from that and put him in the number six role. Being the sort of person he is he was comfortable in doing that. I saw some huge growth in him as a captain and a player. "As a captain, he is only going to get better. It was a little bit tougher for Dewi Lake in only starting one game. He didn’t have as much responsibility, but he was fantastic in the way he supported Jac. I haven’t thought about what happens moving forward. "At the time having two youngsters who were respected by an older group of players who they supported, fitted for us at the World Cup. It’s the first time I’ve done that, and I’m probably not in favour of doing that unless it is required again. We will probably go back to the one-captain scenario."

newsArray.title: Babar Azam continues to lead ICC ODI Batting Rankings
creator: The Frontier Post
newsArray.description: Monitoring Desk DUBAI: Pakistan captain Babar Azam managed to hold on to his number-one position in the International Cricket Council (ICC) Men’s ODI Batting Rankings. newsArray.content: Monitoring Desk DUBAI: Pakistan captain Babar Azam managed to hold on to his number-one position in the International Cricket Council (ICC) Men’s ODI Batting Rankings. Babar, who scored an anchoring half-century against arch-rivals India on Saturday, got the reward for his performance as he kept India’s batting prodigy Shubman Gill at bay. The right-handed Indian batter is ranked second with 818 rating points, in touching distance with Babar Azam, who occupies the top position with 836 points. Meanwhile, Pakistan opening batters Fakhar Zaman and Imam-ul-Haq, who were recently among the Top 10 batters, are now ranked 13th and 10th respectively. In-form South African opener Quinton de Kock, who scored back-to-back centuries in the ongoing ICC World Cup 2023 pipped his teammate Rassie van der Dussen to claim the third position in the rankings. Indian captain Rohit Sharma made a big leap of five places to sixth after amassing 131 runs against Afghanistan then backing it up with an imperious 86 from 63 balls against arch-rivals Pakistan. Afghanistan opener Rahmanullah Gurbaz — jumping 19 spots to 18th — and Netherlands captain Scott Edwards — climbing 16 places to 27th — made notable surges in the batting rankings. In the ICC ODI bowling rankings, however, experienced New Zealand pacer Trent Boult is in touching distance to occupy the top spot following a destructive spell against Bangladesh. He is a mere one rating point behind leader Josh Hazlewood after ascending a place in the latest update. Boult, who returned figures of 2/45 against Bangladesh after also dismissing Towhid Hridoy, also completed 200 wickets in ODIs. Afghanistan’s Rashid Khan climbs to fourth in bowling rankings while South Africa’s Keshav Maharaj jumps seven spots to equal fifth alongside Mujeeb Ur Rahman.

newsArray.title: Pakistan ‘under extra pressure’ in India with no fans
creator: The Frontier Post
newsArray.description: BENGALURU (Agencies): Pakistan paid a heavy price for being “under extra pressure” in their World Cup defeat by arch-rivals India, said batsman Saud Shakeel, who Wednesday lamented the absence of the team’s passionate supporters from the tournament. Pakistan were thrashed by seven wickets on Saturday at Ahmedabad’s 132,000-capacity stadium where there was only a handful […]
newsArray.content: BENGALURU (Agencies): Pakistan paid a heavy price for being “under extra pressure” in their World Cup defeat by arch-rivals India, said batsman Saud Shakeel, who Wednesday lamented the absence of the team’s passionate supporters from the tournament. Pakistan were thrashed by seven wickets on Saturday at Ahmedabad’s 132,000-capacity stadium where there was only a handful of Pakistani supporters. Babar Azam’s team slumped from a solid 155-2 in the 30th over to be dismissed for a paltry 191. “I think we were under extra pressure so we tried to get out of that and wanted to play shots,” Shakeel told AFP on Wednesday. The smattering of Pakistani fans at the game were expatriates from the United Kingdon and United States. Supporters from across the border are effectively banned after a failure to gain visas. The Pakistan Cricket Board (PCB) on Wednesday lodged an official complaint with the world governing body over the visa delays which have also kept many members of the country’s media at home. The PCB also complained over what they described as the “inappropriate behavior” of Indian fans toward the Pakistan squad at the Ahmedabad game. “When you have your crowd then you get the support. We did not get that and it was not in our hands,” added Shakeel. Despite an eighth loss in eight World Cup meetings with their arch-rivals, Pakistan are still well-placed in the tournament after wins over the Netherlands and Sri Lanka. Middle-order batsman Shakeel scored 68 against the Netherlands before making 31 in the game with Sri Lanka. He was out for just six against India. Next up for Pakistan is another high-profile duel, this time with five-time champions Australia in Bengaluru on Friday. “The mistakes we committed in the last game, we must overcome them. That match is gone. If we win against Australia then our position will get better,” added Shakeel. “Australia are always good in the World Cup. They are a very good side. We know our strong areas and we must play good cricket.” “We had a good start to the tournament with two wins. We want to go match by match and not commit the mistakes we did against India.” On Wednesday, all the Pakistan players with the exception of Mohammad Haris trained in Bengaluru. Haris is still suffering from a fever which laid low many of the squad when they arrived from Ahmedabad. Star fast bowler Shaheen Shah Afridi and opener Abdullah Shafique were the worst hit but were present in the nets at the Chinnaswamy Stadium.
